Gunsten de&sr; Nehmer&sr; und wider da&sr; aufgebrachte Schiff geneigt. Da&sr; widerspricht
aber den Grundprincipien aller Recht&sr;pflege, welche ihrer beschränkten Einsicht ein-
gedenk und nur mit äußern Mitteln wirkend nur die <g>offenbare Schuld</g> bedroht,
nicht die verborgene Sünde, und darf daher nicht von dem Völkerrecht gebilligt
werden, auch wenn die Völkersitte solche Mißgriffe noch duldet. Die Schuld muß
also, wenn sie bestritten wird, <g>erwiesen</g> werden, ebenso wie jede andere straf-
bare Schuld.</p>
<d4>856.</d4>
<p>Wird die Nehmung gutgeheißen, so wird da&sr; Eigenthum an Schiff
und Ladung, in so weit al&sr; beide mit Recht genommen sind, sei e&sr; dem
Nehmestat mit Belohnung de&sr; Nehmer&sr;, sei e&sr; diesem selber je nach Um-
ständen mit gewissen Auflagen an den Nehmestat zugesprochen. Nur die
genommenen Krieg&sr;schiffe und die Krieg&sr;contrebande fallen jederzeit dem
Nehmestat, nicht dem Nehmer zu.</p>
<p>Der ganze Gedanke und die Erklärung de&sr; Prisenrecht&sr; wei&sr;t auf da&sr; Noth-
recht de&sr; Kriege&sr; und daher die Krieg&sr;gewalt hin. Niemand kann ein persönliche&sr;
Beuterecht au&sr;sprechen. Eben deßhalb hat auch die Stat&sr;autorität allein darüber
zu verfügen, wem die Prise zufallen soll. Wenn der Nehmer dieselbe zu Eigenthum
bekommt, so kann er diese&sr; Eigenthum nur von der Stat&sr;autorität, nicht von seiner
eigenen Arbeit ableiten. Der Stat kann e&sr; ihm ganz oder theilweise oder gar nicht
geben. Lord <g>Stowell</g> vgl. <g>Phillimore</g> <aq>III. § 128: &201E;Prize i&sr; altogether a
creature of the Crown. No man ha&sr;, or can have any intere&sr;t, but what
he take&sr; a&sr; the mere gift of the Crown; beyond the extent of that gift he
ha&sr; nothing&201C;.</aq> Aber e&sr; können in einem Lande besondere Maximen festgestellt
<pb="463"/>
<kt>Recht der Neutralität.</kt>
werden über die Bedingungen und da&sr; Maß der Belohnung de&sr; Nehmer&sr;, und da&sr;
Prisengericht de&sr; Lande&sr; richtet sich in seinen Entscheidungen darnach.</p>
<d4>857.</d4>
<p>Da&sr; Völkerrecht hindert nicht die Versilberung der in neutralem
Hafen geborgenen Prise zum Vollzug de&sr; Urtheil&sr;. Aber wenn der neu-
trale Stat gegen da&sr; Verfahren de&sr; Prisengericht&sr; völkerrechtliche Beschwer-
den zu führen hat, so ist er, um sein Beschwerderecht zu sichern, berechtigt,
auch diese Versilberung zu untersagen.</p>
<p>Vgl. zu § 845. 847.</p>
<d4>858.</d4>
<p>Die neutralen Eigenthümer haben da&sr; Urtheil de&sr; Prisengericht&sr;
auch ihrerseit&sr; in so weit anzuerkennen, al&sr; nicht der neutrale Stat, dem
sie angehören, wegen völkerrecht&sr;widrigen Verfahren&sr; sie zum Widerspruch
ermächtigt.</p>
<p>Vgl. zu § 842. 845. 847. 848.</p>
<d4>859.</d4>
<p>Die in geordnetem Verfahren dem Nehmestat oder dem Nehmer
zugesprochene Prise kann nicht mehr durch Reprise demselben entzogen
werden, sondern nur durch eine neue berechtigte Prise de&sr; feindlichen
Nehmer&sr;.</p>
<p>Die <g>Reprise</g> (Wiedernahme, <aq>recapture</aq>) ist nur so lange möglich, al&sr; die
Prise gleichsam in der Schwebe ist. Wenn erst diese durch den Spruch de&sr; Prisen-
gericht&sr; in ihren Wirkungen vollendet worden ist, dann hat die Prise selber auf-
gehört. Da&sr; Schiff ist nun in dem unzweifelhaften Eigenthum dessen, dem e&sr; zu-
gesprochen ist. Wenn ihm da&sr;selbe von dem Feinde wieder weggenommen wird, so
ist da&sr; ganz ebenso, wie wenn ihm ein andere&sr; Schiff, da&sr; er ursprünglich durch
Kauf erworben hatte, weggenommen wird. Da&sr; ist eine <g>neue Prise</g>, und nicht
mehr eine Reprise. E&sr; folgt da&sr; au&sr; dem gewohnheit&sr;rechtlichen Satze, daß da&sr;
Urtheil de&sr; Prisengericht&sr; <g>Recht schaffe</g>, auch für die betheiligten Parteien. Wenn
da&sr; au&sr; irgend einem Grunde nicht der Fall ist, dann liegt auch kein Grund vor, die
Anwendung der Reprise au&sr;zuschließen.</p>
<pb="464"/>
<kt>Neunte&sr; Buch.</kt>
<d4>860.</d4>
<p>Vor der gerichtlichen Verurtheilung der Prise kann dem Nehmer die
Prise durch Reprise wieder abgenommen werden. In diesem Falle ist
jedoch da&sr; neutrale Eigenthum von dem Wiedernehmer zu respectiren.</p>
<p>1. Bi&sr; da&sr; Prisengericht über die Prise erkannt und dieselbe verurtheilt hat,
ist da&sr; Schicksal derselben immer noch ungewiß, und noch kein formelle&sr; Recht de&sr;
Nehmestat&sr; oder de&sr; Nehmer&sr; an dem genommenen Schiffe oder der Waare vor-
handen. Bi&sr; dahin kann die Wirksamkeit der Prise, die zunächst auf die Gewalt
der Krieg&sr;macht gegründet ist, wieder ebenfall&sr; durch Gewalt <g>unwirksam gemacht</g>
werden. E&sr; ist da&sr; eine besondere Anwendung de&sr; <g><aq>po&sr;tliminium,</aq></g> eine <g><aq>in
integrum re&sr;titutio.</aq></g> Die Beute wird dem Erbeuter wieder abgejagt.</p>
<p>2. Weil die Reprise zunächst nur <g>negativ</g> wirkt, al&sr; <g>Verneinung</g> der
Prise, und nicht selber eine neue Prise ist noch sein will, so muß der <g>Wieder-
nehmer</g> (<aq>recaptor</aq>) auch da&sr; Eigenthum seinerseit&sr; respectiren, da&sr; er au&sr; der
feindlichen Wegnahme gerettet hat, und er kann nur, je nach Umständen, für die
Arbeiten und Opfer, welche er auf die Reprise verwendet hat, eine angemessene <g>Ent-
schädigung</g> (<aq>&sr;ervaticium</aq>) verlangen, die zuweilen zur Vermeidung von Streit
und Bewei&sr; auf einen <g>Achttheil (amerikanische&sr;</g> Gesetz von 1800. Cap. 14.
und <g>englische&sr;</g> 17 Victor. <aq>c.</aq> 18) oder <g>gar</g> auf einen <g>Drittheil de&sr; Werth&sr;</g>
der Reprise angesetzt ist. Schon der <g><aq>Con&sr;olato del Mar&sr;e c.</aq></g> 287 hat diese
Regel anerkannt.</p>
<p>3. Manche Recht&sr;gelehrte und Lande&sr;ordnungen beschränken die Reprise noch
mehr, z. B.: bi&sr; da&sr; genommene Schiff in einen sichern Hafen gebracht worden ist,
oder: in den ersten 24 Stunden nach der Wegnahme. Wo besondere Gesetze da&sr; so
bestimmen, müssen dieselben wohl geachtet werden. Die Natur der Dinge und die
gerechten Bedenken gegen jede Au&sr;dehnung de&sr; Prisenrecht&sr; rechtfertigen meine&sr; Er-
achten&sr; die Regel de&sr; Text&sr;.</p>
<d4>861.</d4>
<p>Sobald der Friede geschlossen ist, so hört auch alle&sr; Recht, Prisen
zu machen, auf. Die nach dem Frieden&sr;schluß &2014; wenn auch in gutem
Glauben &2014; vollzogenen Nehmungen sind sofort wieder zurückzugeben.</p>
<p>Vgl. oben § 709.</p>
<d4>862.</d4>
<p>Die Prisengerichte sind, wenn nicht der Frieden&sr;schluß ander&sr; be-
<pb="465"/>
<kt>Recht der Neutralität.</kt>
stimmt, berechtigt, die vor demselben anhängig gemachten Prisenprocesse
auch nach demselben fortzuführen und durch Urtheil zu erledigen.</p>
<p>Oft wird durch den Frieden bestimmt, daß alle genommenen, aber noch nicht
verurtheilten Schiffe frei gegeben werden sollen. Ist da&sr; nicht geschehen, so duldet
da&sr; <g>herkömmliche</g> Völkerrecht die Fortsetzung und Vollendung der Prisenprocesse
auch nach dem Abschluß de&sr; Frieden&sr;, obwohl gegen dieselben da&sr; ernste Bedenken
erhoben werden kann, daß die Prisengericht&sr;barkeit nur Krieg&sr;- und nicht Frieden&sr;-
gericht&sr;barkeit ist.</p>
<hr>

<d3><b><aq>In&sr;truction&sr; for the Government of Armie&sr; of the
United State&sr; in the field.</aq></b></d3>
<d4><b><aq>Section I.</aq></b></d4>
<arg><c><i><aq>Martial law &2014; Military juri&sr;diction &2014; Military nece&sr;&sr;ity &2014; Retaliation.</aq></i></c></arg>
<d5>1.</d5>
<p><aq>A place, di&sr;trict, or country occupied by an enemy &sr;tand&sr;, in
con&sr;equence of the occupation, under the Martial Law of the in-
vading or occupying army, whether any proclamation declaring Mar-
tial Law, or any public warning to the inhabitant&sr;, ha&sr; been i&sr;&sr;ued
or not. Martial Law i&sr; the immediate and direct effect and con-
&sr;equence of occupation or conque&sr;t.</aq></p>
<p><aq>The pre&sr;ence of a ho&sr;tile army proclaim&sr; it&sr; Martial Law.</aq></p>
<d5>2.</d5>
<p><aq>Martial Law doe&sr; not cea&sr;e during the ho&sr;tile occupation, ex-
cept by &sr;pecial proclamation, ordered by the commander-in-chief;
or by &sr;pecial mention in the treaty of peace concluding the war,
when the occupation of a place or territory continue&sr; beyond the
conclu&sr;ion of peace a&sr; one of the condition&sr; of the &sr;ame.</aq></p>
<pb="470"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<d5>3.</d5>
<p><aq>Martial Law in a ho&sr;tile country con&sr;i&sr;t&sr; in the &sr;u&sr;pen&sr;ion,
by the occupying military authority, of the criminal and civil law,
and of the dome&sr;tic admini&sr;tration and government in the occupied
place or territory, and in the &sr;ub&sr;titution of military rule and force
for the &sr;ame, a&sr; well a&sr; in the dictation of general law&sr;, a&sr; far a&sr;
military nece&sr;&sr;ity require&sr; thi&sr; &sr;u&sr;pen&sr;ion, &sr;ub&sr;titution, or dictation.</aq></p>
<p><aq>The commander of the force&sr; may proclaim that the admini-
&sr;tration of all civil and penal law &sr;hall continue, either wholly or
in part, a&sr; in time&sr; of peace, unle&sr;&sr; otherwi&sr;e ordered by the mili-
tary authority.</aq></p>
<d5>4.</d5>
<p><aq>Martial Law i&sr; &sr;imply military authority exerci&sr;ed in accor-
dance with the law&sr; and u&sr;age&sr; of war. Military oppre&sr;ion i&sr; not
Martial Law; it i&sr; the abu&sr;e of the power which that law confer&sr;.
A&sr; Martial Law i&sr; executed by military force, it i&sr; incumbent upon
tho&sr;e who admini&sr;ter it to be &sr;trictly guided by the principle&sr; of
ju&sr;tice, honor, and humanity &2014; virtue&sr; adorning a &sr;oldier even
more than other men, for the very rea&sr;on that he po&sr;&sr;e&sr;&sr;e&sr; the
power of hi&sr; arm&sr; again&sr;t the unarmed.</aq></p>
<d5>5.</d5>
<p><aq>Martial Law &sr;hould be le&sr;&sr; &sr;tringent in place&sr; and countrie&sr;
fully occupied and fairly conquered. Much greater &sr;everity may be
exerci&sr;ed in place&sr; or region&sr; where actual ho&sr;tilitie&sr; exi&sr;t, or are
expected and mu&sr;t be prepared for. It&sr; mo&sr;t complete &sr;way i&sr;
allowed &2014; even in the commander&2019;&sr; own country &2014; when face to
face with the enemy, becau&sr;e of the ab&sr;olute nece&sr;&sr;itie&sr; of the
ca&sr;e, and of the paramount duty to defend the country again&sr;t
inva&sr;ion.</aq></p>
<p><aq>To &sr;ave the country i&sr; paramount to all other con&sr;ideration&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>6.</d5>
<p><aq>6. All civil and penal law &sr;hall continue to take it&sr; u&sr;ual
cour&sr;e in the enemy&2019;&sr; place&sr; and territorie&sr; under Martial Law,</aq>
<pb="471"/>
<kt>Amerikanische Krieg&sr;artikel der Vereinigten Staten von 1863.</kt>
<aq>unle&sr;&sr; interrupted or &sr;topped by order of the occupying military
power; but all the function&sr; of the ho&sr;tile government &2014; legi&sr;lative,
executive, or admini&sr;trative &2014; whether of a general, provincial, or
local character, cea&sr;e under Martial Law, or continue only with the
&sr;anction, or if deemed nece&sr;&sr;ary, the participation of the occupier
or invader.</aq></p>
<d5>7.</d5>
<p><aq>Martial Law extend&sr; to property, and to per&sr;on&sr;, whether they
are &sr;ubject&sr; of the enemy or alien&sr; to that government.</aq></p>
<d5>8.</d5>
<p><aq>Con&sr;ul&sr;, among American and European nation&sr;, are not diplo-
matic agent&sr;. Neverthele&sr;&sr;, their office&sr; and per&sr;on&sr; will be &sr;ub-
jected to Martial Law in ca&sr;e&sr; of urgent nece&sr;&sr;ity only: their pro-
perty and bu&sr;ine&sr;&sr; are not exempted. Any delinquency they commit
again&sr;t the e&sr;tabli&sr;hed military rule may be puni&sr;hed a&sr; in the
ca&sr;e of any other inhabitant, and &sr;uch puni&sr;hment furni&sr;he&sr; no
rea&sr;onable ground for international complaint.</aq></p>
<d5>9.</d5>
<p><aq>The function&sr; of Amba&sr;&sr;ador&sr;, Mini&sr;ter&sr;, or other diplomatic
agent&sr;, accredited by neutral power&sr; to the ho&sr;tile government, cea&sr;e,
&sr;o far a&sr; regard&sr; the di&sr;placed government; but the conquering or
occnpying power u&sr;ually recognize&sr; them a&sr; temporarily accredited
to it&sr;elf.</aq></p>
<d5>10.</d5>
<p><aq>Martial Law affect&sr; chiefly the police and collection of public
revenue and taxe&sr;, whether impo&sr;ed by the expelled government or
by the invader, and refer&sr; mainly to the &sr;upport and efficiency of
the army, it&sr; &sr;afety, and the &sr;afety of it&sr; operation&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>11.</d5>
<p><aq>The law of war doe&sr; not only di&sr;claim all cruelty and bad</aq>
<pb="472"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<aq>faith concerning engagement&sr; concluded with the enemy during the
war, but al&sr;o the breaking of &sr;tipulation&sr; &sr;olemnly contracted by
the belligerent&sr; in time of peace, and avowedly intended to remain
in force in ca&sr;e of war between the contracting power&sr;.</aq></p>
<p><aq>It di&sr;claim&sr; all extortion&sr; and other tran&sr;action&sr; for individual
gain; all act&sr; of private revenge, or connivance at &sr;uch act&sr;.</aq></p>
<p><aq>Offence&sr; to the contrary &sr;hall be &sr;everely puni&sr;hed, and e&sr;pe-
cially &sr;o if committed by officer&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>12.</d5>
<p><aq>Whenever fea&sr;ible, Martial Law i&sr; carried out in ca&sr;e&sr; of in-

<d5>13.</d5>
<p><aq>Military juri&sr;diction i&sr; of two kind&sr;: fir&sr;t, that which i&sr; con-

<p><aq>In the armie&sr; of the United State&sr; the fir&sr;t i&sr; exerci&sr;ed by

<d5>14.</d5>

<d5>17.</d5>

<p><aq>When the commander of a be&sr;ieged place expel&sr; the non-

<d5>20.</d5>
<p><aq>Public war i&sr; a &sr;tate of armed ho&sr;tility between &sr;overeign

<d5>22.</d5>

<d5>23.</d5>
<p><aq>Private citizen&sr; are no longer murdered, en&sr;laved, or carried

<d5>24.</d5>
<p><aq>The almo&sr;t univer&sr;al rule in remote time&sr; wa&sr;, and continue&sr;

<d5>27.</d5>
<p><aq>The law of war can no more wholly di&sr;pen&sr;e with retaliation

nation&sr; acknowledge retaliation a&sr; the &sr;terne&sr;t feature of war. A

<d5>28.</d5>
<p><aq>Retaliation will, therefore, never be re&sr;orted to a&sr; a mea&sr;ure

<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<aq>moreover, cautiou&sr;ly and unavoidably; that i&sr; to &sr;ay, retaliation &sr;hall

<p><aq>Unju&sr;t or incon&sr;iderate retaliation remove&sr; the belligerent&sr;
farther and farther from the mitigating rule&sr; of a regular war, and
by rapid &sr;tep&sr; lead&sr; them nearer to the internecine war&sr; of &sr;avage&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>29.</d5>
<p><aq>Modern time&sr; are di&sr;tingui&sr;hed from earlier age&sr; by the exi-

<p><aq>Peace i&sr; their normal condition; war i&sr; the exception. The

<p><aq>The more vigorou&sr;ly war&sr; are pur&sr;ued, the better it i&sr; for

<d5>30.</d5>
<p><aq>Ever &sr;ince the formation and coexi&sr;tence of modern nation&sr;,

<p><aq>There exi&sr;t&sr; no law or body of authoritative rule&sr; of action

<d5>42.</d5>
<p><aq>Slavery, complicating and confounding the idea&sr; of property,
(that i&sr; of a <i>thing</i>,) and of per&sr;onalty, (that i&sr; of <i>humanity,</i>) exi&sr;t&sr;

<d5>43.</d5>
<p><aq>Therefore, in a war between the United State&sr; and a belli-

belligerent be captured by or come a&sr; a fugitive under the protection</aq>
<pb="480"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<aq>of the military force&sr; of the United State&sr;, &sr;uch per&sr;on i&sr; imme-

by the law of war i&sr; under the &sr;hield of the law of nation&sr;, and
the former owner or State can have, by the law of po&sr;t-liminy, no
belligerent lien or claim of &sr;ervice.</aq></p>
<d5>44.</d5>
<p><aq>All wanton violence committed again&sr;t per&sr;on&sr; in the invaded

<p><aq>A &sr;oldier, officer or private, in the act of committing &sr;uch

<p><aq>Neither officer&sr; nor &sr;oldier&sr; are allowed to make u&sr;e of their

<d4><b><aq>Section III.</aq></b></d4>

<d5>49.</d5>
<p><aq>A pri&sr;oner of war i&sr; a public enemy armed or attached to
the ho&sr;tile army for active aid, who ha&sr; fallen into the hand&sr; of

<p><aq>The monarch and member&sr; of the ho&sr;tile reigning family,

make&sr; no difference on account of the difference of &sr;exe&sr;, concerning
the &sr;py, the war-traitor, or the war-rebel.</aq></p>
<d5>103.</d5>
<p><aq>Spie&sr;, war-traitor&sr;, and war-rebel&sr; are not exchanged according
to the common law of war. The exchange of &sr;uch per&sr;on&sr; would
require a &sr;pecial cartel, authorized by the government, or, at a
great di&sr;tance from it, by the chief commander of the army in
the field.</aq></p>
<d5>104.</d5>
<p><aq>A &sr;ucce&sr;&sr;ful &sr;py or war-traitor, &sr;afely returned to hi&sr; own
army, and afterward&sr; captured a&sr; an enemy, i&sr; not &sr;ubject to puni&sr;h-
ment for hi&sr; act&sr; a&sr; a &sr;py or war-traitor, but he may be held in
clo&sr;er cu&sr;tody a&sr; a per&sr;on individually dangerou&sr;.</aq></p>
<d4><b><aq>Section VI.</aq></b></d4>
<arg><c><i><aq>Exchange of pri&sr;oner&sr; &2014; Flag&sr; of truce &2014; Flag&sr; of protection.</aq></i></c></arg>
<d5>105.</d5>
<p><aq>Exchange&sr; of pri&sr;oner&sr; take place&2014;number for number&2014;rank
for rank&2014;wounded for wounded&2014;with added condition for added
condition&2014;&sr;uch, for in&sr;tance a&sr; not to &sr;erve for a certain period.</aq></p>
<d5>106.</d5>
<p><aq>In exchanging pri&sr;oner&sr; of war, &sr;uch number&sr; of per&sr;on&sr; of
inferior rank may be &sr;ub&sr;tituted a&sr; an equivalent for one of &sr;uperior</aq>
<pb="494"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<aq>rank a&sr; may be agreed upon by cartel, which require&sr; the &sr;anction
of the government, or of the commander of the army in the field.</aq></p>
<d5>107.</d5>
<p><aq>A pri&sr;oner of war i&sr; in honor bound truly to &sr;tate to the
captor hi&sr; rank: and he i&sr; not to a&sr;&sr;ume a lower rank than belong&sr;
to him, in order to cau&sr;e a more advantageou&sr; exchange; nor a

<p><aq>Offence&sr; to the contrary have been ju&sr;tly puni&sr;hed by the
commander&sr; of relea&sr;ed pri&sr;oner&sr;, and may be good cau&sr;e for refu&sr;ing
to relea&sr;e &sr;uch pri&sr;oner&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>108.</d5>
<p><aq>The &sr;urplu&sr; number of pri&sr;oner&sr; of war remaining after an
exchange ha&sr; taken place i&sr; &sr;ometime&sr; relea&sr;ed either for the pay-

clothing, or other nece&sr;&sr;arie&sr;.</aq></p>
<p><aq>Such arrangement, however, require&sr; the &sr;anction of the highe&sr;t
authority.</aq></p>
<d5>109.</d5>
<p><aq>The exchange of pri&sr;oner&sr; of war i&sr; an act of convenience to
both belligerent&sr;. If no general cartel ha&sr; been concluded, it cannot
be demanded by either of them. No belligerent i&sr; obliged to ex-

<p><aq>A cartel i&sr; voidable &sr;o &sr;oon a&sr; either party ha&sr; violated it.</aq></p>
<d5>110.</d5>
<p><aq>No exchange of pri&sr;oner&sr; &sr;hall be made except after complete
capture, and after an accurate account of them, and a li&sr;t of the
captured officer&sr;, ha&sr; been taken.</aq></p>
<d5>111.</d5>
<p><aq>The bearer of a flag of truce cannot in&sr;i&sr;t upon being admit-</aq>
<pb="495"/>
<kt>Amerikanische Krieg&sr;artikel der Vereinigten Staten von 1863.</kt>
<aq>ted. He mu&sr;t alway&sr; be admitted with great caution. Unnece&sr;&sr;ary
frequency i&sr; carefully to be avoided.</aq></p>
<d5>112.</d5>
<p><aq>If the bearer of a flag of truce offer him&sr;elf during an enga-
gement, he can be admitted a&sr; a very rare exception only. It i&sr;
no breach of good faith to retain &sr;uch a flag of truce, if admitted

<d5>113.</d5>
<p><aq>If the bearer of a flag of truce, pre&sr;enting him&sr;elf during an
engagement, i&sr; killed or wounded, it furni&sr;he&sr; no ground of com-
plaint whatever.</aq></p>
<d5>114.</d5>
<p><aq>If it be di&sr;covered, and fairly proved, that a flag of truce ha&sr;
been abu&sr;ed for &sr;urreptitiou&sr;ly obtaining military knowledge, the
bearer of the flag thu&sr; abu&sr;ing hi&sr; &sr;acred character i&sr; deemed a &sr;py.</aq></p>
<p><aq>So &sr;acred i&sr; the character of a flag of truce, and &sr;o nece&sr;&sr;ary
i&sr; it&sr; &sr;acredne&sr;&sr;, that while it&sr; abu&sr;e i&sr; an e&sr;pecially heinou&sr; of-
fence, great caution i&sr; requi&sr;ite, on the other hand, in convicting
the bearer of a flag of truce a&sr; a &sr;py.</aq></p>
<d5>115.</d5>
<p><aq>It i&sr; cu&sr;tomary to de&sr;ignate by certain flag&sr;, (u&sr;ually yellow,)
the ho&sr;pital&sr; in place&sr; which are &sr;helled, &sr;o that the be&sr;ieging enemy
may avoid firing on them. The &sr;ame ha&sr; been done in battle&sr;, when
ho&sr;pital&sr; are &sr;ituated within the field of the engagement.</aq></p>
<d5>116.</d5>
<p><aq>Honorable belligerent&sr; often reque&sr;t that the ho&sr;pital&sr; within
the territory of the enemy may be de&sr;ignated, &sr;o that they may be
&sr;pared.</aq></p>
<pb="496"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<p><aq>An honorable belligerent allow&sr; him&sr;elf to be guided by flag&sr;
or &sr;ignal&sr; of protection a&sr; much a&sr; the contingencie&sr; and the nece&sr;-
&sr;itie&sr; of the fight will permit.</aq></p>
<d5>117.</d5>
<p><aq>It i&sr; ju&sr;tly con&sr;idered an act of bad faith, of infamy or fiend-

<d4><b><aq>Section VII.</aq></b></d4>
<arg><c><i><aq>The Parole.</aq></i></c></arg>
<d5>119.</d5>
<p><aq>Pri&sr;oner&sr; of war may be relea&sr;ed from captivity by exchange
and, under certain circum&sr;tance&sr;, al&sr;o by parole.</aq></p>
<d5>120.</d5>
<p><aq>The term Parole de&sr;ignate&sr; the pledge of individual good faith
and honor to do, or to omit doing, certain act&sr; after he who give&sr;
hi&sr; parole &sr;hall have been di&sr;mi&sr;&sr;ed, wholly or partially, from the
power of the captor.</aq></p>
<d5>121.</d5>
<p><aq>The pledge of the parole i&sr; alway&sr; an individual, but not a
private, act.</aq></p>
<d5>122.</d5>
<p><aq>The parole applie&sr; chiefly to pri&sr;oner&sr; of war whom the captor</aq>
<pb="497"/>
<kt>Amerikanische Krieg&sr;artikel der Vereinigten Staten von 1863.</kt>
<aq>allow&sr; to return to their country, or to live in greater freedom
within the captor&2019;&sr; country or territory, on condition&sr; &sr;tated in the
parole.</aq></p>
<d5>123.</d5>
<p><aq>Relea&sr;e of pri&sr;oner&sr; of war by exchange i&sr; the general rule;
relea&sr;e by parole i&sr; the exception.</aq></p>
<d5>124.</d5>
<p><aq>Breaking the parole i&sr; puni&sr;hed with death when the per&sr;on
breaking the parole i&sr; captured again.</aq></p>
<p><aq>Accurate li&sr;t&sr;, therefore, of the paroled per&sr;on&sr; mu&sr;t be kept
by the belligerent&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>125.</d5>
<p><aq>When parole&sr; are given and received there mu&sr;t be an ex-
change of two written document&sr;, in which the name and rank of
the paroled individual&sr; are accurately and truthfully &sr;tated.</aq></p>
<d5>126.</d5>
<p><aq>Commi&sr;&sr;ioned officer&sr; only are allowed to give their parole,
and they can give it only with the permi&sr;&sr;ion of their &sr;uperior, a&sr;
long a&sr; a &sr;uperior in rank i&sr; within reach.</aq></p>
<d5>127.</d5>
<p><aq>No non-commi&sr;&sr;ioned officer or private can give hi&sr; parole
except through an officer. Individual parole&sr; not given through an
officer are not only void, but &sr;ubject the individual giving them to
the puni&sr;hment of death a&sr; de&sr;erter&sr;. The only admi&sr;&sr;ible excep-
tion i&sr; where individual&sr;, properly &sr;eparated from their command&sr;,
have &sr;uffered long confinement without the po&sr;&sr;ibility of being pa-
roled through an officer.</aq></p>
<bs><g>Bluntschli</g>, Da&sr; Völkerrecht. 32</bs>
<pb="498"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<d5>128.</d5>
<p><aq>No paroling on the battle-field; no paroling of entire bodie&sr;
of troop&sr; after a battle; and no di&sr;mi&sr;&sr;al of large number&sr; of pri-
&sr;oner&sr;, with a general declaration that they are paroled, i&sr; permit-
ted, or of any value.</aq></p>
<d5>129.</d5>
<p><aq>In capitulation&sr; for the &sr;urrender of &sr;trong place&sr; or fortified
camp&sr; the commanding officer, in ca&sr;e&sr; of urgent nece&sr;&sr;ity, may
agree that the troop&sr; under hi&sr; command &sr;hall not fight again du-
ring the war, unle&sr;&sr; exchanged.</aq></p>
<d5>130.</d5>
<p><aq>The u&sr;ual pledge given in the parole i&sr; not to &sr;erve during
the exi&sr;ting war, unle&sr;&sr; exchanged.</aq></p>
<p><aq>Thi&sr; pledge refer&sr; only to the active &sr;ervice in the field,
again&sr;t the paroling belligerent or hi&sr; allie&sr; actively engaged in the
&sr;ame war. The&sr;e ca&sr;e&sr; of breaking the parole are patent act&sr;, and
can be vi&sr;ited with the puni&sr;hment of death; but the pledge doe&sr;

cruit&sr;, fortifying place&sr; not be&sr;ieged, quelling civil commotion&sr;,
figthing again&sr;t belligerent&sr; unconnected with the paroling belli-
gerent&sr;, or to civil or diplomatic &sr;ervice for which the paroled officer
may be employed.</aq></p>
<d5>131.</d5>
<p><aq>If the government doe&sr; not approve of the parole, the paroled
officer mu&sr;t return into captivity, and &sr;hould the enemy refu&sr;e to
receive him, he i&sr; free of hi&sr; parole.</aq></p>
<d5>132.</d5>
<p><aq>A belligerent government may declare, by a general order,
whether it will allow paroling, and on what condition&sr; it will allow
it. Such order i&sr; communicated to the enemy.</aq></p>
<pb="499"/>
<kt>Amerikanische Krieg&sr;artikel der Vereinigten Staten von 1863.</kt>
<d5>133.</d5>
<p><aq>No pri&sr;oner of war can be foreed by the ho&sr;tile government
to parole him&sr;elf, and no government i&sr; obliged to parole pri&sr;oner&sr;
of war, or to parole all captured officer&sr;, if it parole&sr; any. A&sr; the
pledging of the parole i&sr; an individual act, &sr;o i&sr; paroling, on the
other hand, an act of choice on the part of the belligerent.</aq></p>
<d5>134.</d5>
<p><aq>The commander of an occupying army may require of the civil
officer&sr; of the enemy, and of it&sr; citizen&sr;, any pledge he may con-
&sr;ider nece&sr;&sr;ary for the &sr;afety or &sr;ecurity of hi&sr; army, and upon
their failure to give it he may arre&sr;t, confine, or detain them.</aq></p>
<d4><b><aq>Section VIII.</aq></b></d4>
<arg><c><i><aq>Armi&sr;tice&2014;Capitulation.</aq></i></c></arg>
<d5>135.</d5>
<p><aq>An armi&sr;tice i&sr; the ce&sr;&sr;ation of active ho&sr;tilitie&sr; for a period
agreed upon between belligerent&sr;. It mu&sr;t be agreed upon in
writing, and duly ratified by the highe&sr;t authoritie&sr; of the conten-
ding partie&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>136.</d5>
<p><aq>If an armi&sr;tice be declared, without condition&sr;, it extend&sr; no
further than to require a total ce&sr;&sr;ation of ho&sr;tilitie&sr;, along the front
of both belligerent&sr;.</aq></p>
<p><aq>If condition&sr; be agreed upon, they &sr;hould be clearly expre&sr;&sr;ed,
and mu&sr;t be rigidly adhered to by both partie&sr;. If either party
violate&sr; any expre&sr;&sr; condition, the armi&sr;tice may be declared null
and void by the other.</aq></p>
<d5>137.</d5>
<p><aq>An armi&sr;tice may be general, and valid for all point&sr; and</aq>
<bs>32*</bs>
<pb="500"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<aq>line&sr; of the belligerent&sr;; or &sr;pecial, that i&sr;, referring to certain troop&sr;
or certain localitie&sr; only.</aq></p>
<p><aq>An armi&sr;tice may be concluded for a definite time; or for an
indefinite time, during which either belligerent may re&sr;ume ho&sr;tilitie&sr;
on giving the notice agreed upon to the other.</aq></p>
<d5>138.</d5>
<p><aq>The motive&sr; which induce the one or the other belligerent to
conclude an armi&sr;tice, whether it be expected to be preliminary to a
treaty of peace, or to prepare during the armi&sr;tice for a more vi-
gorou&sr; pro&sr;ecution of the war, doe&sr; in no way affect the character
of the armi&sr;tice it&sr;elf.</aq></p>
<d5>139.</d5>
<p><aq>An armi&sr;tice i&sr; binding upon the belligerent&sr; from the day of
the agreed commencement; but the officer&sr; of the armie&sr; are re&sr;pon-
&sr;ible from the day only when they receive official information of
it&sr; exi&sr;tence.</aq></p>
<d5>140.</d5>
<p><aq>Commanding officer&sr; have the right to conclude armi&sr;tice&sr;
binding on the di&sr;trict over which their command extend&sr;, but &sr;uch
armi&sr;tice i&sr; &sr;ubject to the ratification of the &sr;uperior authority, and
cea&sr;e&sr; &sr;o &sr;oon a&sr; it i&sr; made known to the enemy that the armi&sr;tice
i&sr; not ratified, even if a certain time for the elap&sr;ing between gi-
ving notice of ce&sr;&sr;ation and the re&sr;umption of ho&sr;tilitie&sr; &sr;hould have
been &sr;tipulated for.</aq></p>
<d5>141.</d5>
<p><aq>It i&sr; incumbent upon the contracting partie&sr; of an armi&sr;tice
to &sr;tipulate what intercour&sr;e of per&sr;on&sr; or traffic between the in-
habitant&sr; of the territorie&sr; occupied by the ho&sr;tile armie&sr; &sr;hall be
allowed, if any.</aq></p>
<pb="501"/>
<kt>Amerikanische Krieg&sr;artikel der Vereinigten Staten von 1863.</kt>
<p><aq>If nothing i&sr; &sr;tipulated the intercour&sr;e remain&sr; &sr;u&sr;pended, a&sr;
during actual ho&sr;tilitie&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>142.</d5>
<p><aq>An armi&sr;tice i&sr; not a partial or a temporary peace; it i&sr; only
the &sr;u&sr;pen&sr;ion of military operation&sr; to the extent agreed upon by
the partie&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>143.</d5>
<p><aq>When an armi&sr;tice i&sr; concluded between a fortified place and
the army be&sr;ieging it, it i&sr; agreed by all the authoritie&sr; on thi&sr;
&sr;ubject that the be&sr;ieger mu&sr;t cea&sr;e all exten&sr;ion, perfection, or ad-
vance of hi&sr; attacking work&sr; a&sr; much &sr;o a&sr; from attack&sr; by main
force.</aq></p>
<p><aq>But a&sr; there i&sr; a difference of opinion among martial juri&sr;t&sr;,
whether the be&sr;ieged have the right to repair breache&sr; or to erect
new work&sr; of defence within the place during an armi&sr;tice, thi&sr;
point &sr;hould be determined by expre&sr;&sr; agreement between the
partie&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>144.</d5>
<p><aq>So &sr;oon a&sr; a capitulation i&sr; &sr;igned, the capitulator ha&sr; no right
to demoli&sr;h, de&sr;troy, or injure the work&sr;, arm&sr;, &sr;tore&sr;, or ammunition,
in hi&sr; po&sr;&sr;e&sr;&sr;ion, during the time which elap&sr;e&sr; between the &sr;igning
and the execution of the capitulation, unle&sr;&sr; otherwi&sr;e &sr;tipulated in
the &sr;ame.</aq></p>
<d5>145.</d5>
<p><aq>When an armi&sr;tice i&sr; clearly broken by one of the partie&sr;,
the other party i&sr; relea&sr;ed from all obligation to ob&sr;erve it.</aq></p>
<d5>146.</d5>
<p><aq>Pri&sr;oner&sr;, taken in the act of breaking an armi&sr;tice, mu&sr;t be
treated a&sr; pri&sr;oner&sr; of war, the officer alone being re&sr;pon&sr;ible who</aq>
<pb="502"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<aq>give&sr; the order for &sr;uch a violation of an armi&sr;tice. The highe&sr;t
authority of the belligerent aggrieved may demand redre&sr;&sr; for the
infraction of an armi&sr;tice.</aq></p>
<d5>147.</d5>
<p><aq>Belligerent&sr; &sr;ometime&sr; conclude an armi&sr;tice while their pleni-
potentiarie&sr; are met to di&sr;cu&sr;&sr; the condition&sr; of a treaty of peace;
but plenipotentiarie&sr; may meet without a preliminary armi&sr;tice; in
the latter ca&sr;e, the war i&sr; carried on without any abatement.</aq></p>
<d4><b><aq>Section IX.</aq></b></d4>
<arg><c><i><aq>A&sr;&sr;a&sr;&sr;ination.</aq></i></c></arg>
<d5>148.</d5>
<p><aq>The law of war doe&sr; not allow proclaiming either an indivi-
dual belonging to the ho&sr;tile army, or a citizen, or a &sr;ubject of the
ho&sr;tile government, an outlaw, who may be &sr;lain without trial by
any captor, anymore than the modern law of peace allow&sr; &sr;uch
international outlawry; on the contrary, it abhor&sr; &sr;uch outrage.
The &sr;terne&sr;t retaliation &sr;hould follow the murder committed in con-
&sr;equence of &sr;uch proclamation, made by whatever authority. Civi-
lized nation&sr; look with horror upon offer&sr; of reward&sr; for the a&sr;&sr;a&sr;-
&sr;ination of enemie&sr; a&sr; relap&sr;e&sr; into barbari&sr;m.</aq></p>
<d4><b><aq>Section X.</aq></b></d4>
<arg><c><i><aq>In&sr;urrection&2014;Civil War&2014;Rebellion.</aq></i></c></arg>
<d5>149.</d5>
<p><aq>In&sr;urrection i&sr; the ri&sr;ing of people in arm&sr; again&sr;t their gov-
ernment, or a portion of it, or again&sr;t one or more of it&sr; law&sr;, or</aq>
<pb="503"/>
<kt>Amerikanische Krieg&sr;artikel der Vereinigten Staten von 1863.</kt>
<aq>again&sr;t an officer or officer&sr; of the government. It may be confined
to mere armee re&sr;i&sr;tance, or it may have greater end&sr; in view.</aq></p>
<d5>150.</d5>
<p><aq>Civil war i&sr; war between two or more portion&sr; of a country
or State, each contending for the ma&sr;tery of the whole, and each
claiming to be the legitimate government. The term i&sr; al&sr;o &sr;ome-
time&sr; applied to war af rebellion, when the rebelliou&sr; province&sr; or
portion&sr; of the State are contiguou&sr; to tho&sr;e containing the &sr;eat
of government.</aq></p>
<d5>151.</d5>
<p><aq>The term rebellion i&sr; applied to an in&sr;urrection of large ex-
tent, and i&sr; u&sr;ually a war between the legitimate government
of a country and portion&sr; or province&sr; of the &sr;ame who &sr;eek to
throw off their allegiance to it, and &sr;et up a government of their
own.</aq></p>
<d5>152.</d5>
<p><aq>When humanity induce&sr; the adoption of the rule&sr; of regular
war toward rebel&sr;, whether the adoption i&sr; partial or entire, it doe&sr;
in no way whatever imply a partial or complete acknowledgment of
their government, if they have &sr;et up one, or of them, a&sr; an inde-
pendent or &sr;overeign power. Neutral&sr; have no right to make the
adoption of the rule&sr; of war by the a&sr;&sr;ailed government toward
rebel&sr; the ground of their own acknowledgment of the revolted
people a&sr; an independent power.</aq></p>
<d5>153.</d5>
<p><aq>Treating captured rebel&sr; a&sr; pri&sr;oner&sr; of war, exchanging them,
concluding of cartel&sr;, capitulation&sr;, or other warlike agreement&sr; with
them; addre&sr;&sr;ing officer&sr; of a rebel army by the rank they may
have in the &sr;ame; accepting flag&sr; of truce; or, on the other hand,
proclaiming martial law in their territory, or levying war-taxe&sr; or
forced loan&sr;, or doing any other act &sr;anctioned or demanded by the</aq>
<pb="504"/>
<kt>Anhang.</kt>
<aq>law and u&sr;age&sr; of public war between &sr;overeign belligerent&sr;, neither
prove&sr; nor e&sr;tabli&sr;he&sr; an acknowledgment of the rebelliou&sr; people,
or of the government which they may have erected, a&sr; a public
or &sr;overeign power. Nor doe&sr; the adoption of the rule&sr; of war
toward rebel&sr; imply an engagement with them extending beyond
the limit&sr; of the&sr;e rule&sr;. It i&sr; victory in the field that end&sr; the
&sr;trife and &sr;ettle&sr; the future relation&sr; between the contending partie&sr;.</aq></p>
<d5>154.</d5>
<p><aq>Treating, in the field, the rebelliou&sr; enemy according to the
law and u&sr;age&sr; of war ha&sr; never prevented the legitimate govern-
ment from trying the leader&sr; of the rebellion or chief rebel&sr; for high
trea&sr;on, and from treating them accordingly, unle&sr;&sr; they are inclu-
ded in a general amne&sr;ty.</aq></p>
<d5>155.</d5>
<p><aq>All enemie&sr; in regular war are divided into two general cla&sr;-
&sr;e&sr;; that i&sr; to &sr;ay, into combatant&sr; and non-combatant&sr;, or unarmed
citizen&sr; of the ho&sr;tile government.</aq></p>
<p><aq>The military commander of the legitimate government, in a war
of rebellion, di&sr;tingui&sr;he&sr; between the loyal citizen in the revolted
portion of the country and the di&sr;loyal citizen. The di&sr;loyal citizen&sr;
may further be cla&sr;&sr;ified into tho&sr;e citizen&sr; known to &sr;ympathize
with the rebellion, without po&sr;itively aiding it, and tho&sr;e who, with-
out taking up arm&sr;, give po&sr;itive aid and comfort to the rebelliou&sr;
enemy, without being bodily forced thereto.</aq></p>
<d5>156.</d5>
<p><aq>Common ju&sr;tice and plain expediency require that the military
commander protect the manife&sr;tly loyal citizen&sr;, in revolted territo-
rie&sr;, again&sr;t the hard&sr;hip&sr; of the war a&sr; much a&sr; the common
mi&sr;fortune of all war admit&sr;.</aq></p>
<p><aq>The commander will throw the burden of the war, a&sr; much
a&sr; lie&sr; within hi&sr; power, on the di&sr;loyal citizen&sr; of the revolted
portion or province, &sr;ubjecting them to a &sr;tricter police than the</aq>
<pb="505"/>
<kt>Amerikanische Krieg&sr;artikel der Vereinigten Staten von 1863.</kt>
<aq>non-combatant enemie&sr; have to &sr;uffer in regular war; and if he
deem&sr; it appropriate, or if hi&sr; government demand&sr; of him that
every citizen &sr;hall, by an oath of allegiance, or by &sr;ome other ma-
nife&sr;t act, declare hi&sr; fidelity to the legitimate government, he may
expel, tran&sr;fer, impri&sr;on, or fine the revolted citizen&sr; who refu&sr;e to
pledge them&sr;elve&sr; anew a&sr; citizen&sr; obedient to the law and loyal
to the government.</aq></p>
<p><aq>Whether it i&sr; expedient to do &sr;o, and whether reliance can
be placed upon &sr;uch oath&sr;, the commander or hi&sr; government have
the right to decide.</aq></p>
<d5>157.</d5>
<p><aq>Armed or unarmed re&sr;i&sr;tance by &sr;itizen&sr; of the United State&sr;
again&sr;t the lawful movement&sr; of their troop&sr; i&sr; levying war again&sr;t
the United State&sr;, and i&sr; therefore trea&sr;on.</aq></p>
